questions.question: What is TCP/IP?
questions.explanation: TCP/IP: fundamental protocols. Layers: multiple. Development: DARPA. Standard: de facto internet standard. Reliability: basis for internet. Coverage: physical to application. Importance: modern networks.

questions.question: What is a protocol stack?
questions.explanation: Stack: hierarchical protocols. Function: each layer adds value. Communication: layers interact. Example: TCP/IP has 4-5 layers. Purpose: organization, separation of concerns. Importance: abstraction.

questions.question: What is IP (Internet Protocol)?
questions.explanation: IP: fundamental protocol. Function: logical addressing, routing. Versions: IPv4, IPv6. Datagrams: basic unit. Header: contains addresses. Importance: foundation.

questions.question: What is TCP (Transmission Control Protocol)?
questions.explanation: TCP: ensures delivery. Features: sequencing, error checking, flow control. Connection: three-way handshake. Stream: data flow. Importance: email, web, file transfer.

questions.question: What is UDP (User Datagram Protocol)?
questions.explanation: UDP: minimal overhead. Features: none (no sequencing). Speed: fast. Connectionless: no handshake. Usage: real-time, speed critical. Importance: streaming, gaming, DNS.

questions.question: What is ICMP?
questions.explanation: ICMP: error reporting. Messages: ping, traceroute. Purpose: network diagnostics. Mechanism: ECHO request/reply. Importance: troubleshooting. Security: can be used for attacks.

questions.question: What is IGMP?
questions.explanation: IGMP: manages multicast groups. Purpose: multicast reception. Versions: IGMPv1, v2, v3. Routers: track memberships. Importance: video distribution. Usage: streaming services.

questions.question: What is multicast?
questions.explanation: Multicast: single source, multiple destinations. Efficiency: bandwidth saving. Addresses: 224.0.0.0 - 239.255.255.255. Example: video streaming. vs Unicast: one-to-one.

questions.question: What is broadcast?
questions.explanation: Broadcast: all devices in network. Address: .255 (e.g., 192.168.1.255). Efficiency: flooding. Limitation: only local network. Example: DHCP discovery. Impact: traffic.

questions.question: What is unicast?
questions.explanation: Unicast: specific destination. Standard: typical communication. Efficiency: direct delivery. Scalability: works for all. Example: web browsing. Importance: most common.
